title: Compact Lie algebras, transversely Lie foliations and fibrations

title_detail.value: Compact Lie algebras, transversely Lie foliations and fibrations

summary:
We study Lie foliations on compact manifolds, in case the Lie group is
compact. Our main results improve Tischler classical result on the existence of
fibration and, as an application, we study the case the manifold has an
amenable fundamental group.

1

Introduction

An important theorem due to Tischler states that a smooth closed manifold fibers over the qdimensional torus if and only if admits a foliation given by q linearly independent closed forms
of degree one. Indeed, given q linearly independent closed forms of degree one, it is possible to
find new closed forms arbitrarily close to the originals and having rational periods. The foliation
defined by these new forms has all leaves compact and these leaves are the fibers of a locally
trivial fibration over the torus. All this can be seen as embedded in the theory of Lie-foliations
[10], [12]. Let g be a Lie algebra of dimension q and let M be a smooth closed manifold. We
say that a foliation F of codimension q on M is a g-Lie foliation if, given structure constants
{ckij } of g, there exists a system {ω1 , . . . , ωq } of linearly independent smooth forms of degree
P
one on M which satisfies dωk = − i<j ckij ωi ∧ ωj and whose kernel is tangent to F. Let G be
a connected Lie group having g as Lie algebra. A foliation F on M is a Lie g-foliation if and
only if F admits a Lie transverse structure modeled by G (see [12]), that is, F is defined by
local submersions taking values on G with transition maps given by left translations on G. The
existence of Lie foliation does not guarantee the existence of a global submersion of M in G. The
difficulty in obtaining such a submersion from a Lie foliation F can be measured by the global
holonomy group of F with respect to G, which is a representation of the fundamental group of
M in G. In his thesis, Fedida proves that, in fact, the structure of F is strongly related to its
global holonomy ([10], [12]). In this work, we obtain a generalization of the Tischler fibration
Theorem for g-Lie foliations, when g is a compact Lie algebra, in the sense that g is the Lie
algebra of some compact Lie group:
1

 Theorem 1. Let g be a compact Lie algebra, M a smooth closed manifold and F a Lie gfoliation on M . Let G be a connected compact Lie group having g as Lie algebra. If the closure
of the global holonomy of F with respect to G has Abelian Lie algebra, then M possesses a finite
covering which fibers over G. Indeed, there is a finite covering of M where the lifting of F can
be C 0 -approximated by Lie g-foliations having all leaves compact.
The proof of Theorem 1 gives a description of the structure of the foliation, and this allows
us to well understand the finite covering mentioned. Combining our result with a result due to
Caron and Carrière ([6]), we have
Corollary 1. Let g be a semisimple compact Lie algebra and let F be a (not necessarily minimal) one-dimensional Lie g-foliation on a smooth closed manifold M . We have
1. there is a finite covering of M where the lifting of F can be C 0 -approximated by Lie
g-foliations having all leaves compact;
2. If G is the simply connected Lie group having g as Lie algebra, then M possesses a finite
covering which fibers over G.
An important remark in the theory is that the closure of the global holonomy of a Lie
foliation must be an Abelian group provided that the fundamental group of M is Abelian.
In this work, we extend this observation by proving that if the fundamental group of M is
amenable and G is compact, then the closure of the global holonomy of F has Abelian Lie
algebra. Thus, we can apply Theorem A to obtain the following:
Theorem 2. Let g be a compact Lie algebra and M a smooth closed manifold with amenable
fundamental group. If M admits a Lie g-foliation, then there is a finite covering of M where
the lifted foliation can be C 0 -approximated by Lie g-foliations having all leaves compact. If G
is a compact Lie group having g as Lie algebra, then M possesses a finite covering which fibers
over G.
We also studied the particular case where the fundamental group of the ambient manifold
has subexponential growth and g is not necessarily compact:
Theorem 3. Let M be a smooth closed manifold with fundamental group of subexponential
growth and suppose that M admits a Lie g-foliation. We have:
1. If G is a connected Lie group having g as Lie algebra, then G has polynomial volume
growth;
2. If s < g is a Levi factor of g and S is a connected Lie group having s as Lie algebra, then
S is compact and M possesses a finite covering which fibers over S.
In the semisimple case, the result above has the following statement:
Corollary 2. Let M be a smooth closed manifold which admits a Lie g-foliation where g is a
semisimple Lie algebra. If g is non-compact then the fundamental group of M has exponential
growth. If the fundamental group of M has subexponential growth then any connected Lie group
G having g as Lie algebra is compact and M possesses a finite covering which fibers over G.
The concept of Lie foliations admits a natural generalization: Let G be a connected Lie group
of dimension n and let K be a connected closed Lie subgroup of G of dimension n − q. Let g and
k be the Lie algebras of G and K, respectively. Let β = {X1 , . . . , Xq , Xq+1 , . . . , Xn } be a basis

manifold M admits n smooth forms of degree one ω1 , . . . , ωq , ωq+1 , . . . , ωn
satisfying dωk = − i<j ckij ωi ∧ ωj . If the forms ω1 , . . . , ωq are linearly independent at each
point of M , then they define a foliation F of codimension q on M and, for this case, we can

modeled by G/K (see [2], [12]), that is, F is defined by local submersions taking values on
G/K with transition maps given by left translations on G. Similar structures are constructed,
as a global holonomy group ([12], [2]). We should note, however, that not every transversely
homogeneous foliation is obtained from global forms of degree one. Our preceding results together with results of Blumenthal ([2], [3]), give the following fibration result for transversely
homogeneous foliations:
Theorem 4. Let G be a connected compact Lie group, K a closed and connected subgroup of
G and let M be a smooth closed manifold with amenable fundamental group. Given a G/Ktransversely homogeneous foliation F on M , suppose one of the following conditions is satisfied
1. H 1 (M, K) is trivial;
2. the normal bundle of F is trivial and G/K is a simply-connected Riemannian homogeneous space of constant curvature.
Then there is a finite covering of M where the lifting of F can be C 0 -approximated by G/Ktransversely homogeneous foliations. Moreover, M possesses a finite covering which fibers over
G/K.
We stress that conditions (1) and (2) in Theorem 4 above are used in order to assure that the
homogeneous transverse structure is given by globally defined one-forms and can be replaced
by this hypothesis, which may also verified in some other situations.
Corollary 3. Let F be an one-dimensional SO(2q + 1)/SO(2q)-transversely homogeneous foliation with trivial normal bundle on a smooth closed manifold M . Then there is a finite covering
of M where the lifting of F can be C 0 -approximated by SO(2q + 1)/SO(2q)-foliations having
all leaves compact. If M is orientable and q = 1, then the finite covering mentioned is either
the identity or a double covering of M .

Foliations invariant under transverse actions

The Lie g-foliation in Example 2 has a special property: there is a smooth action φ on the
ambient manifold which preserve the leaves of F and whose orbits are transversal to F. The
same is true for the foliation G defined on M × G in Darboux-Fedida's Theorem. They are part
of a special class of foliations called G-i.u.t.a. foliations ([1]), which we describe more formally:
Let G be a q-dimensional connected Lie group and G a codimension q foliation on a smooth
manifold E. We say that G is a G-i.u.t.a. foliation (or invariant under transverse action of G)
if there is a smooth locally free action φ of G on E whose orbits are transverse to G and such
that, for each g ∈ G, φg take leaves of G diffeomorphically over leaves of G. In [1], the authors
construct a development for this class of foliations. In particular, if g is the Lie algebra of G,
then a G-i.u.t.a. foliation is a Lie g-foliation. The converse is not necessarily true (see [1]).

such that each fiber is a G-saturated subset of E. Moreover, G induces on the fiber containing
L a minimal Lie h-foliation, where h is the Lie algebra of de Γ.

Lemma 2. Let G be a connected Lie group. If a finitely generated subgroup Γ < G is amenable,
then there is a solvable subgroup Q < Γ such that [Γ : Q] < ∞.
Proof. Let Ad : G → GL(g, R) be the adjoint homomorphism. Since Γ is finitely generated,
either Ad(Γ) has a non-cyclic free subgroup or Ad(Γ) is virtually solvable (Tits Alternative
[24]). Since Ad(Γ) is an amenable group, the first option does not occur. Therefore, there is a
solvable subgroup E of Ad(Γ) such that [Ad(Γ) : E] < ∞. Writing T = Ad−1 (E), we have that

Proposition 3. Let M be a smooth closed manifold with amenable fundamental group and let
F = FΩ be a Lie g-foliation on M . Let G be a connected Lie group having g as Lie algebra
and let Γ = Γ(Ω, G) be the global holonomy of F. The connected component of Γ containing
the identity is a solvable Lie subgroup of G. In particular, if G is compact, then the connected
component of Γ containing the identity is Abelian.
Proof. Since π1 (M ) is amenable, Γ is amenable. Denote by Γ0 the connected component of
Γ containing the identity. Let Q be the solvable subgroup of Γ given by Lemma 2. Taking
the closure of the derived series of Q, we conclude that Q is solvable. Therefore Γ0 ∩ Q is a
closed subgroup of Γ0 and a solvable group. By Lemma 1, [Γ, Q] < ∞ and this implies that
[Γ0 , Γ0 ∩ Q] < ∞. Since Γ0 is connected, we conclude that Γ0 = Γ0 ∩ Q is solvable. Then, Γ0 is
a connected solvable Lie group. If G is compact, then Γ0 is compact and, thus, Abelian.

In this section, we study Lie foliations on manifolds with fundamental growth of subexponential

Lemma 3. Let G be a connected Lie group and Γ < G a finitely generated subgroup of subexponential growth. There is a nilpotent subgroup T < Γ such that [Γ : T ] < ∞.
Proof. Since Γ has subexponential growth, Γ is amenable. Let Q < Γ be the solvable subgroup
given by Lemma 2. Since [Γ : Q] < ∞, Q is a finitely generated solvable group of subexponential
growth. By Milnor-Wolf Theorem ([19], [26]) Q is virtually nilpotent, that is, there is a nilpotent
subgroup T of Q [Q : T ] < ∞. We have [Γ : T ] < ∞ and, by Lemma 1, [Γ : T ] < ∞.

Proposition 5. Let M be a smooth closed manifold with fundamental group of subexponential
growth. If M admits a Lie g-foliation and G is a connected Lie group having g as Lie algebra,
then G has polynomial volume growth.
Proof. Let F = FΩ be such foliation and let Γ = Γ(Ω, F) be the global holonomy of F. Using
Fedida Fibration Theorem, we conclude that G/Γ is compact. By [18], Γ is compactly generated.
It follows from Theorem I.4 of [14] that G and Γ has the same volume growth. Let T be the
nilpotent subgroup of Γ given by Lemma 3. Since [Γ : T ] < ∞, T is compactly generated and
has the same volume growth of of Γ and, thus, of G. Taking the closure of the lower central
series of T , we obtain a central series for T and, thus T is a nilpotent group. By Theorem II.4
of [14], T (and thus G) has polynomial volume growth.
Given a Lie algebra g, there is a solvable ideal of g that contains all the solvable ideals of g.
This ideal is called radical of g and we will denote it by r(g). We have that g is solvable if and
only if r(g) = g; g is semisimple if and only if r(g) = 0, that is, if and only if g has no solvable
ideal. If G is a connected Lie group having g as Lie algebra, then the radical of G is the Lie
subgroup of G having r(g) as Lie algebra.

A remark about Riemannian foliations

This section is concerned with the study of Riemannian foliations and contains results already
found in [22]. Let M be a smooth manifold and F a smooth foliation on M of codimension q.
Denote by X (F) the set of smooth vector fields on M which are tangent to F. We say that a
vector field X on M is foliated with respect to F if
[X, Y ] ∈ X (F),

for all Y ∈ X (F).

If N F is the normal bundle of F and X is a foliated vector field, we can project X over
N F, obtaining a vector field X tangent to N F. We say that X is the transversal vector field
associated with X. We say that a foliation F is transversely parallelizable if its normal bundle
admits a trivialization by q linearly independent transversal foliated vector fields. Every Lie
foliation is a transversely parallelizable foliation, however, the reciprocal is not necessarily true.
We say that a Riemannian metric g on M is bundle-like with respect to a foliation F if,
given an open U ⊂ M and foliated vector fields X, Y on U orthogonal to the leaves of F, the
function g(X, Y ) is constant along the leaves of F|U . For all details, see [20]. We say that F
is a Riemannian foliation if there exists a bundle-like metric with respect to F. A deep result
due to Molino describes the structure of transversely parallelizable and Riemannian foliations
and proves that the study of such foliations is closely related to the study of Lie foliations:
Molino's structure theorem ([12, 20]). Let M be a connected closed manifold and let F be
a foliation on M .
1. If F is transversally parallelizable, then the closures of the leaves of F are the fibers of
a locally trivial basic fibration π : M → B. The restriction of F to each fiber defines a
Lie g-foliation with dense leaves. The Lie algebra g is an algebraic invariant of F called
structural Lie algebra of F.

 2. If F is a transversally orientable Riemannian foliation and τ : M ′ → M is the principal SO(q)-bundle of orthonormal frames transverse to F, then F lifts to a transversally
parallelizable foliation F ′ on M ′ such that
• dim F ′ = dim F;
• F ′ is invariant by the action of SO(q).
The structural Lie algebra of F ′ is an invariant of F called structural Lie algebra of F.
